I have to say for a team of paid professionals their output is quite low. I mean, I know some crazy people on fanfiction and art sites who pump out more good stuff in their freaking free-time, completly reliant on donations and comissions. Sure it's not always the best quality, but it's sometimes truly remakrable.

And then you have the Riot team who slams out a few pages every half year, and that does look kinda sad in comparision...

The problem with that is that Riot need to take every little detail into consideration in order to build a connected world or we would end up with the mess that was pre retcon League, my guess is that Riot are working on both a darkin story and a Noxus update

Yes, obviously higher quality demands more time needed for the content, but that doesn't in any way justify an output THAT low. 

And there are always corners of the world that you can write short-stories of, like something about the daily live of Piltover/Demacia/Zaun/Shurima, literally wheverever, then run it through a checklist of things you are not allowed to spoil, the run it thorugh a checklist to avoid cultural incoherence, and if magic is involved, run it through another checklist with that system. Then get it proofread, edited, and wop, here's your weekly/monthly short-story.

You can't tell me than an entire team fo professional writers can't clank out 5-10 pages per month because they are sooo busy on these 50 or so pages that will be coming in the next lore event? That's just ridiculous.
My guess is Riot employees can be on multiple teams at the same time and I doubt any one person is only writing lore.

Well, they have hired professional writers. Now, what other team would you put am professinal writer on? Graphics design? Coding? Managing Esports? You know, game designers might get handed around reworks, new champs, and cliant work and so on. But writers? Nope.

Actually you'd be surprised. While working where I was before, I was just a Production Coordination Assistant with some hand in writing quests. At the same time I was also the resident video editor. Simply put, you can be tasked with things that go with your strengths. I could write and I could edit videos, so there I was.

At one point,  I had to communicate with the level designer in real-time on the phone, because while I was wriitng the quest and its dialogue, I needed to know exactly a) what was in this scene, b) what can the player actually do and c) was there any other scripted events in the scenario that I had to account for.

Now League is different in that the lore isn't an interactable component of the game. 

However, here's a simple example - What color should this character's powers be described in? Does it have a special distinctive sound effect? What are its in-game effects?

When selling the character's story, they have to match what is seen in the game. To do that they must communicate with the game designers. And the game designers actually have precedence - the color chosen might be because of game mechanics, where they're higher contrast or more visible. The sound effect chosen is because they need to make the character unique amongst  the huge cast and have the ability be instantly recognizable.

The writing team can contribute flavor text and the like, which then needs to be sent to the VO and their team to determine which lines can be kept, which lines are too long for the given limits of the game and so on. The game programmers on their end, may need to know if certain lines are triggered by specific events (for special interactions), which means they have to coordinate with the VO team to know exactly the audio cut-off lengths to prevent triggers overriding each other.

And this doesn't take into account the approval of the creative director or other editors and heads, who need to sign-off on what ultimately is chosen.

For an interactive medium, no one department stands alone, simply by virtue of what a game is.

A little reality check, no disrespect meant but it's about the difference between writing for yourself, and for an entire organization.

A fanfic writer is their own writer, proofreader, editor, creative director, asset manager, reviewer, and final eye checker, all at once. All they have to say is 'yes' to themselves.

In a company where the creative output that gets signed off has repercussions, affecting the production of future stories or assets down-the-line, there is no way any one person gets to sign off on something, and getting a consensus and think-tank to come together to first decide on what to do, and then to edit and finalize the actual product, takes a shit ton of time.

Consider even more that Riot is trying to build a more cohesive lore, then there is great stakes involved. An off-hand or inaccurate remark in any written official lore would not only be a mark of low quality in QA, but also have potentially frustrating repercussions down the line if they don't rectify it.

This is the reality of working and writing for an organization. No one person has full control, even the creative director has to usually answer to the producer, who gets to put their input as well, or collaborates on equal footing with their editor, and so on. This is the reality of a creative project from many minds.

And as I wrote before in another reply, higher quality takes more time, that's just logical. What irks me is that still with an entire team working we get as much output every half YEAR to what very passionate individuals create in a few days to times. Yes, you need to make it coherent, you need to check it with release shedules so it fits, get your editor look over it, re-do it, and so and and so on. It's all important. 

Yet that doesn't explain the current level of output, which is abyssimal low compared to what a team should be capable of with that time-frame.
